availability.p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

div.head: 18.3.1882 Samstag
div.p: We started up to London by the 8.35 up train. We arrived at Waterloo at about 9.30. The Head Sneyd-Kynnersley had hired some S. W railway busses by the day, for 15/-15 Schilllings each to drive about in. We first had ourselves jolted to the Baker street bazaar where we arrived in rather the worse for wear or rather shaking, for the coachman, a cadaverous looking person, seemed to take great pleasure in driving up all „impasses“ and into all the rocks he could possibly think of or find. I suppose he was the conductor of a funeral car and was perhaps in hopes that the shaking might be fatal to one of the more delicate of our party and that he might be the driver of the funeral car. However we did arrive at Baker street without being quite turned upside down. After that we jolted on to the Zoo where we saw Jumbo. He eat a great many buns but ungratefully rejected the sack which we gave him. We saw the others fed and and went into a small house where we saw some „armadilloes.“ We then drove to M r Bald’s to have dinner. We sat over dinner till so late that we got to the theatre 20 minutes too late. We saw two pieces: „Dearer than life“ Byron and „Domestic economy“ Lemon . In the latter a labourer who was keeping his shop while his wife was out was very rude to his customers: he sent herrings and tallow candles after them and told one who complained how sticky the brandyballs were that it was because his son sucked them and put them back into the box. We afterwards drove to the South-Kensington Victoria and Albert Museum ; we saw the „Rocket“ the first steam engine ever made and the same which ran over Huskisson there. We did not get back to Ascot till a quarter to ten.
